meeting_annotations.speaker: Marcel Schreier
meeting_annotations.transcript: I have a kind of almost a kind of fundamental concern. So first of all I don't want to discredit research on nitrogen reduction because I think from a scientific perspective it's fascinating. This dinitrogen bond is fascinating. But when we then look at an engineering perspective when we think about what we need to do to do an electrochemical transformation of nitrogen now we just think at scale right. We need to bring in dinitrogen and we need to bring in protons and we need to bring in current. So we need obviously it's kind of a triple phase boundary or or kind of a gas diffusion electrode kind of design. This will be very difficult especially for bringing in the gaseous species which is very weakly soluble. I think that's where people struggle. Whereas if we are generating hydrogen in an electrolyzer we have no transport problem we just can bring water to the reaction site with very high transport rates generate hydrogen get a gas and then convert it together with a second gas nitrogen in a Haber-Bosch process. So I just think when we look at this from this engineering perspective right this need for a triple phase boundary compared to the ease of generating hydrogen electrochemically we may find ourselves in a situation where when we want to do it at scale we may find it hard to compete with a coupled Haber-Bosch and electrolyzer design. I don't know what you guys think.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker uses hand gestures extensively to illustrate complex concepts.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Andrew Teixeira
meeting_annotations.transcript: I might have missed a little bit of that but so you're saying that because the electrochemical route requires the addition of the proton there I mean when I think about that compared to the traditional Haber-Bosch you do need the net thermodynamic states are going to be the same so the net driving forces are the same. So are you saying it's an engineering challenge to get them all co-located on the active site?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Marcel Schreier
meeting_annotations.transcript: a transport where we need the triple phase boundary whereas in a classical catalytic environment we have very good transport between two gases going to an iron-based catalytic site and then turning over to ammonia.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Andrew Teixeira
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean it's been you could argue that that transport has been fine-tuned over you know decades at least for development there of the the fluidized bed technology to get there and I don't know to me it sounds like it's not a scientific barrier it's a technical question of how are we going to do it as opposed to saying even if we do get it it won't be efficient.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Haotian Wang
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think it's it's I agree with Marcel it's a big problem but I also agree with Andrew that it could be solved. Like we can take examples from let's say oxygen reduction in fuel cell. They also need this type of triple phase boundaries but they can deliver very high current density which means that you can also deliver very high production rate per area of your electrode right. But the challenge here now is we don't have as a platinum as efficient in ORR as an unknown catalyst we can have for NRR. That's I think will be the critical challenge here to deliver the the scale that you mentioned to compete with Haber-Bosch.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker effectively synthesizes and builds upon the points of the previous two speakers.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Oana Luca
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sorry. I just want to add a bit of a kind of organic chemist perspective on the matter. I feel like you know we're asked to dream big right and the topic is beyond CO2 and you know come up with the craziest idea we can come up with. And you know on one hand from a chemistry perspective the nitrogen molecule doesn't have a dipole so it's really hard to activate for you at a surface at a molecule you name it. But on the other hand you know I think that there are from a synthetic perspective there are a lot of other products that could be made from a nitrogen reduction process and so you know if that is a way to frame the question not necessarily in terms of replacing Haber-Bosch which we know that is difficult but maybe adding a different kind of value to a process and so something that comes to mind is capturing carbon dioxide converting it to formaldehyde then making ammonia electrocatalytically and there are some systems that do this and then just adding a cyanide source and making amino acids. You know these are basic building blocks for organic synthesis and pharmaceutical science and you know these discussions today have really kind of catalyzed this these ideas where you know maybe we just need to think a little bit bigger right and you know Haber-Bosch is extraordinarily difficult to make an argument against but maybe there are other ways to frame the problem as an opportunity in a different context.
